results.description:
The Software Adventure series was developed by Beam Software/Melbourne House and published for most home computer platforms between 1982 and 1989.

Part of The Lord of the Rings franchise.
results.name: The Lord of the Rings - A Software Adventure

results.description: Overview
results.name: The Land Before Time

results.description:
Overview

The Monster Maker series are games that range from card game simulators to traditional RPGs to fantasy-themed board games similar to the Dokapon series. The franchise saw many adaptations from different developers and publishers putting their own spin on the material.

These games include:

  • The SOFEL games. They produced Monster Maker (1990) and Monster Maker II (1993) for the Game Boy, which were RPGs that used cards for their combat system, and Monster Maker III (1993) for the Super Famicom which had far fewer card game elements.
  • SOFEL also produced the Famicom game Monster Maker: 7-tsu no Hihou (1991).
  • Monster Maker Kids (1994), also from SOFEL, is a board game that uses cards. It was released on the Super Famicom.
  • The Game Boy game Monster Maker: Barcode Saga (1993) from Namco was one of a handful of games to use the Barcode Reader peripheral for the portable.
  • NEC Interchannel's Monster Maker: Yami no Ryuukishi (1994) for the PC Engine CD. This game ended on a cliffhanger, but its Sega Saturn sequel was canceled mid-development.
  • The GBA games Monster Maker: Flash Card (2002) and Monster Maker: Killer Dice (2002). Both versions could communicate with each other, a common feature of the Pokemon series.
results.name: Monster Maker

results.description: An arcade sub-series of the Shining Force series, which is in turn part of the Shining franchise.
results.name: Shining Force Cross

results.description:
Despite starting with Shining in the Darkness, the SEGA franchise has been largely defined by Shining Force entries and numerous other sub-series using the "Shining" branding.

The Shining franchise includes the following sub-series:

  • Shining Force
  • Shining Force Cross
  • Shining Soul
  • Shining Tears X Wind
results.name: Shining

results.description: This series is part of the Shining franchise, which also includes the Shining Force series.
results.name: Shining Soul

results.description:
This is a sub-series of the Shining franchise, which also includes the Shining Force series.

Both games were adapted into the Shining Tears X Wind anime series.
results.name: Shining Tears X Wind

results.description: The Galaga series is part of the Galaxian franchise.
results.name: Galaga

results.description:
The video game adaptions have varied in how close they've been to the source material's turn based, grid based gameplay. Two first person tactical shooter adaptions were published by Electronic Arts in the early 90's, Space Hulk (1993) and Space Hulk: Vengeance of the Blood Angels (1995).

Teardown were working on a straight adaption, with permission from THQ who held the Warhammer 40,000 license at the time, but THQ changed their mind and made them remove all WH40K art from the game, which was then released under the name Alien Assault (2009).

In 2013 Full Control Studios released the grid based strategy game Space Hulk, and in 2014 the stand-alone expansion Space Hulk Ascension was released.
results.name: Space Hulk

results.description:
Overview

Derby Stallion is a series that began on the Famicom in 1991 and continues to the present, with releases as recent as December 2014 for the Nintendo 3DS. Though it has many sequels, each game in the series is iterative, building on the last and adding a few new features and/or a graphical update each time.

Due to the popularity in Japan of horse-racing and the business aspects of developing a stable, and the relative lack of popularity of same in other countries, no Derby Stallion game has ever been released outside of Japan.

Games

A non-exhaustive list follows:

NameSystemDateNotes
Best Keiba Derby StallionFamicom12/21/1991The first game in the series. "Best Keiba" would be dropped from future titles.
Derby Stallion ZengokubanFamicom08/28/1992"Zengokuban" roughly means "National Edition".
Derby Stallion IISuper Famicom02/18/1994The first 16-bit console game in the series.
Derby Stallion IIISuper Famicom01/20/1995
Derby Stallion '96Super Famicom03/15/1996Also released via the Satellaview.
Derby StallionPlayStation07/17/1997The first 32-bit console game in the series.
Derby Stallion '98Super Famicom09/01/1998Released via a special edition of Nintendo Power in Japan.
Derby StallionSaturn03/25/1999A port of the 1997 PlayStation Derby Stallion.
Derby Stallion '99PlayStation09/30/1999
Derby Stallion 64Nintendo 6408/10/2001The first 64-bit console game in the series.
Derby Stallion AdvanceGame Boy Advance12/06/2002The first game in the series for a portable system.
Derby Stallion '04PlayStation 204/22/2002
Derby Stallion PPSP07/27/2006
Derby Stallion DSNintendo DS06/26/2008
Derby Stallion GoldNintendo 3DS12/04/2014
results.name: Derby Stallion

results.description: The Starglider series was Argonaut's first foray into 3D games, and became the basis for the Star Fox series, which was originally prototyped as NESGlider.
results.name: Starglider

results.description: The Touch! Kirby (タッチ！カービィ) series is a sub-series of the Kirby franchise with two current installments. Unlike other platforming games from the series, the first title made the player themselves the protagonist as Kirby is controlled through drawing paths and prodding the touch screen (Kirby, the environment and enemies) rather than inputs serving as abstractions for jumping and floating.
results.name: Touch! Kirby

results.description:
The "Endless" franchise began in 2012 with the release of space 4X game Endless Space by French studio Amplitude Studios. It then expanded with Amplitude releasing three more games, fantasy 4X game Endless Legend, Roguelike/Tower Defense hybrid Dungeon of the Endless, and Endless Space 2

All four of these games share common elements such as the same resources (Dust, Industry, Science, and Food as examples), all have an element of strategy to them, and all take place within the same universe.
results.name: Endless

results.description: For the parent franchise, see Persona.
results.name: Persona 3

results.description: Both games were using the Build engine.
results.name: Witchaven

results.description:
Overview

Power Sports is the collective name for a group of sports games Hudson Soft put out throughout the 1990s, all of which contain "Power" in their title (at least for the Japanese release). Power Sports overlaps with Hudson's Power League series of baseball games, which are all considered part of the greater Power Sports label.

List of Power Sports Games

NameUS TitleReleaseSystemFeatured SportNotes
Power LeagueWorld Class Baseball06/24/1988TG16, X68000BaseballThe first game in the Power League spin-off series.
Power GolfPower Golf05/25/1989TG16GolfRetained the Power name in the US release.
Power ElevenN/A06/21/1991TG16SoccerJP-only.
Power SportsWorld Sports Competition10/10/1992TG16MiscellaneousFeatures Olympics events.
Power TennisN/A06/25/1993TG16TennisJP-only.

This list does not include all the sequels to Power League, which can be found on its franchise page.
results.name: Power Sports

results.description: The PlayStation releases of the first two entries in this franchise were published in North America by Electronic Arts under the Need for Speed brand. The North American release of the Dreamcast version of V-Rally 2 was similarly rebranded as Test Drive V-Rally in order to market the game as part of a more popular franchise.
results.name: V-Rally

results.description: Most of the games have already been released on the platform that the compilation is released on, however in some instances, one or more games in the pack will have not been released individually before.
results.name: 3T Games Compilation

results.description:
The first game was released on the Apple II in 1984, and both it and the sequel were space trading games, whereas the third entry went with a point and click adventure game style.

The games were set in the same universe as Omnitrend's later Breach and Rules of Engagement series.
results.name: Universe

results.description: Action RPG series created by Sein Soft in 1985. One of the pioneers of the Metroidvania format.
results.name: Tritorn

results.description:
These are hack & slash video games based on the Berserk franchise of manga, anime and films. Berserk began as a manga series, which debuted in 1989 and ended in 2021 following the death of its author, Kentaro Miura.

The Berserk manga series notably influenced several popular Japanese role-playing game franchises, including the Final Fantasy series, particularly Final Fantasy VII, and the Souls series of action RPG titles, particularly Dark Souls (as mentioned by Hidetaka Miyazaki in his Giant Bomb interview). It was also a major influence on the SoulCalibur fighting games.
results.name: Berserk

results.description: The first sub-series of the Science Adventure franchise of visual novels.
results.name: Chaos;Head
